content.title: Hybrid Vascular Procedures Overview
content.definition: Surgical approaches combining open vascular techniques with endovascular interventions in a single procedure or staged approach, leveraging the advantages of both modalities.

key_concepts.description: Specially designed OR with fixed imaging (C-arm or robotic angiography), OR-quality lighting and airflow, anesthesia and surgical equipment.
Reduces overall morbidity, treats anatomy unsuitable for single modality, extends endovascular landing zones, provides surgical bailout capability.
Simultaneous: single anesthesia, single procedure. Staged: separate sessions, allows recovery between procedures.

aortic.technique: Open surgical debranching followed by or simultaneous with TEVAR

aortic.indication: Juxtarenal/suprarenal AAA unsuitable for fenestrated grafts
aortic.technique: Retrograde bypass to visceral vessels then EVAR

aortic.procedure: Open Ascending Aortic Repair with Frozen Elephant Trunk
aortic.indication: Extensive aortic disease involving arch and descending aorta
aortic.technique: Open arch repair with antegrade deployment of stent graft

peripheral.indication: Combined aortoiliac and common femoral disease
peripheral.technique: CFE via cutdown with antegrade or retrograde iliac intervention

peripheral.indication: Optimize bypass inflow or outflow vessels
peripheral.technique: Bypass surgery combined with PTA of proximal or distal vessels

mesenteric.procedure: Open Bypass with Endovascular Stenting of Second Vessel
mesenteric.indication: Chronic mesenteric ischemia with multiple vessel disease
mesenteric.technique: Surgical bypass to one vessel, stent another

advantages: Reduced physiologic stress compared to complete open repair
Addresses complex anatomy not suitable for single approach
Immediate bailout capability for endovascular complications
Single anesthesia event reduces cumulative risk
disadvantages: Longer procedure times in some cases
Combines risks of both open and endovascular approaches
Increased cost for hybrid OR infrastructure

hybrid_OR.imaging: Fixed C-arm or ceiling-mounted robotic angiography system
hybrid_OR.table: Radiolucent, adjustable for both imaging and surgery
hybrid_OR.space: Larger than standard OR for equipment
hybrid_OR.staffing: Staff trained in both open surgery and endovascular procedures

learning_objectives: Define hybrid vascular procedures and explain the rationale for their use
List common hybrid procedures for aortic, peripheral, and mesenteric disease
Describe facility and equipment requirements for hybrid vascular surgery
Discuss advantages and disadvantages of hybrid approaches
clinical_pearls: Plan hybrid procedures with entire team - surgeon, interventionalist, anesthesia, nursing
Have bailout plans for both open and endovascular complications
Consider patient fitness - hybrid may allow treatment of patients unfit for complete open repair
